ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about how trade protection (import substitution, export subsidies, etc.) can affect different stakeholders in a nation (consumers, producers, industries, factors of production, government, etc.). You also learn about these effects for the rest of the world.
Important frameworks for evaluating trade policy.

I learned several frameworks with which I can evaluate the impact of various trade policies. I also learned where these models fall short and looked at real-world empirical data to back up certain claims.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this class are that it is small and Professor Maggi is always willing to field questions and provide help. The course is well-structured and the amount of content is balanced. The cons of this course are there is not that much time set aside to interact with and discuss the material.
Strengths: Professor Maggi is awesome, material is usually interesting, and the assignments are not overwhelming. Weaknesses: Mmmm nothing really.

I think the class might benefit more for a little more open-ended discussion, especially since class participation was worth 10% of the grade. The only opportunities during which we got to talk were when we asked questions which felt a little limiting. Other than that, however, I don't really see how this course can be meaningfully improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to a student who is interested at all in trade. I had no background prior to this class and it taught me a lot about what the impacts of trade are.

Yes, I would recommend this course. There is a soft pre-req of ECON 184 for this course, but it really isn't that important to have taken beforehand. Even if you don't become a trade economist, international trade policy is very important today, and this is a great class in which to learn about it.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. As far as Econ senior seminars go, this one was very engaging and felt like a natural extension of some of the material in macro/micro. It was also a pretty low-stress course; professor Maggi is very approachable and eager to help and the material is not very strenuous. Overall, this course was not too difficult while easy to manage and I still learned a lot and found the material to be more interesting than in most economics courses. Easily one of the courses I was most thankful to have taken at Yale.
